III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10165 Resident Nutrition
Section (1) A facility shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious meals daily,
Description unless medically contraindicated and documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth is always starving and has lost 15 pounds since being at
the facility because he's not getting enough food. There are
concerns he is given the same amount of food as youth half his
size. Youth’s mother tried to purchase additional food for him but
was told no. When the facility staff noticed youth started losing
weight, he was given two protein shakes per day in addition to his
regular meals.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 6/28/23.
Complainant was a MDHHS Worker on an investigation on the
facility unrelated to these allegations. Complainant was told the
allegations by Youth A’s mother during a phone call. Complainant
noted Youth A did not mention either of these concerns during his
interview with her for the unrelated investigation.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/28/23.
Youth A reported he has been at the facility since 4/6/23. He
reported he weighed 185lbs when he entered the facility and is
now done to 171lbs. Youth A reported he is not eating as much
protein as he was prior to entering the facility. Youth A stated
when he was at home, he was lifting weights every day and was
eating 10,000-20,000 calories per day, so he was basically eating
all day. Youth A reported while at the facility, he is fed three meals
per day, which includes a meat, a type of vegetable, a side, and a
milk carton. Youth A reported its smaller portions than he’s used
to for everything, so he never feels full. He reported the youth do
not receive second helpings of food. Youth A stated he received
one snack per day in between shift change (i.e., rice Krispie treat,
bag of chips, bag of cookies, package of peanut butter crackers).
Youth A stated now that he’s lost so much weight, he also
receives two Ensure shakes per day (one at breakfast and one at
dinner), but they do not help keep him full either. Youth A reported
he feels like he’s starving every day. Youth A reported he’s written
grievances a few times asking for extra food, but the facility has
denied his requests.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/28/23.
Nurse reported on 6/9/23, Youth A was seen for a routine
appointment and his weight was down 15lbs. Nurse confirmed
2

Youth A weighed 185lbs. on 4/10/23 and weighed 171lbs. on
6/9/23. Due to his weight loss, Nurse talked to the doctor and the
doctor prescribed two Ensure shakes per day, so Youth A was
consuming additional calories. Nurse reported they are required to
follow guidelines from the government regarding calories and use
the government established food pyramid to do so.
Probation Officer was interviewed via phone on 7/12/23.
Probation Officer reported she has no concerns with the care
Youth A is receiving. Probation Officer reported the meals the
youth receive are monitored by a nutritionist and the facility must
follow certain guidelines, which they are following. Probation
Officer reported Youth A receives three meals per day, two
Ensure shakes per day and up to three snacks per day.
Youth A’s Mother was interviewed via phone on 7/12/23.
Mother reported she is very concerned her son has lost 15lbs. in
less than three months. Mother reported they do not take the
youth outside often, so they just do indoor activities one hour per
day. Mother reported Youth A couldn’t go outside for weeks due to
restrictions from the bullet wound on his leg. Mother stated once
he was off restrictions, the facility reported they do more indoor
activities than outdoor because of low staffing. Mother reported
Youth A is used to being outside and working out all the time
because he participates in weightlifting, wrestling and football, so
being in the facility has been difficult for him. Mother reported
Youth A was eating 10,000-20,000 calories of food per day prior to
entering the facility (i.e., 12 pieces of French toast for breakfast,
two massive steaks for dinner, a whole pot of spaghetti). Since his
calorie intake has significantly reduced at the facility, he feels like
he’s starving all the time. Mother reported she has offered to buy
protein powder so he can make his own protein shakes, but she
was told no. Mother reported he began receiving two Ensure
shakes per day, but those shakes are not helping him much
because he still feels he is starving every day. Mother reported
she has also offered to buys snacks for all of the youth at the
facility, so it’s not unfair her son is the only one getting extra food,
but she was told no.
Attempts were made to interview Dietician on 7/21/23 and
7/24/23. A voicemail was left each time, but no return call was
received. Dietician is not employed by the facility. Dietician is
employed by a third party called Canteen Services.
3

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Ottawa County Week 1, 2, 3 and 4 menus for the months
Youth A has resided at the facility. Each menu has three
meals per day listed for all seven days of the week. Each
meal is broken down into specific serving sizes. Each meal
has four components (i.e., meat, grain, fruit, vegetable
and/or starch) and a drink. Dinner meals also include a
dessert. Each menu is approved/signed off on by Dietician
and Chief Administrator. Each one notes the menu is based
on a 2,400+ calorie daily diet.
• Commission on Dietic Registration the credentialing agency
for the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics Credential
Verification for Dietician (7/8/16-8/31/23) states Dietician
has met all appropriate academic, supervised practice,
verification and examination requirements and is in good
standing. Dietician is hired by Canteen Services.
• Ottawa County Juvenile Detention Center Quarterly
Resident Food Surveys dated April 2023 and July 2023 ask
youth questions about whether they feel they are getting
enough food each day, if they like the variety of food, if they
like the quality of food, questions about staff eating with
youth and questions as to whether youth have been denied
food because of disciplinary reasons. In April 2023, 12 out
of 19 youth reported they didn’t feel they received enough
food, but all 19-youth stated they were not being denied
food due to disciplinary reasons. In July 2023, 11 out of 17
youth reported they didn’t feel they received enough food,
but all 17 youth stated they were not being denied food due
to disciplinary reasons.
• Food Services Detention Policy (rev. 12/28/22) states all
youth shall be provided meals that are nutritionally
adequate and properly prepared. Youth in the Detention
Center are provided at least three meals per day, and two
of the meals must be hot. Facility’s system of dietary
allowance is reviewed at least annually by a dietician to
ensure compliance with nationally recommended food
allowances. Menus are developed that recognize the needs
of the general youth population, including distinctions such
as age, sex, physical activity, medical status, etc. Menu
evaluations are conducted quarterly to ensure correct basic
daily servings. Special foods or diets must be prescribed by
a physician or certified dietician. Food surveys are
conducted quarterly. Facility follows all Michigan
4

Department of Education School Lunch Program
Guidelines and USDA rules regulating the School Lunch
Program for the youth served.
• Youth A’s Resident Grievance Form dated 4/23/23. Youth
A reports no one gets full of one tray of food and suggested
they offer additional food for purchase if a youth wants to.
Administrator 2 responded on 4/24/23 stating the facility
cannot offer extra trays of food for purchase due to the
requirements of the school lunch program.
• Medical Notes for Youth A completed by Nurse state Youth
A weighed 185lbs. on 4/7/23, 171lbs. on 6/10/23 and
171lbs. on 7/24/23.
• Doctor Note dated 6/10/23 regarding Youth A’s concern
about weight loss. Doctor notes Youth A is tall, slim and
appears in good condition. Youth A has lost 14 lbs. since
being at the facility. Nursing calculates his BMI to be 20.
Doctor prescribed two Ensure shakes per day to
supplement his diet.
• BMI Calculator for Teens from CDC.Gov website calculates
on 6/9/23 Youth A had a BMI of 20.8, placing him in the
44th percentile for youth his age, which falls in the Healthy
Weight BMI category.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. The facility is following nationally
recognized standards for meals provided to the youth, and the
meals are established and overseen by a licensed dietician. While
Youth A lost 15lbs. in 2 months of being at the facility, he and his
mother also reported prior to entering the facility, Youth A was
eating 5-10x the daily calorie intake he is receiving at the facility.
Youth A’s weight is being monitored by a physician and he was
prescribed two Ensure shakes per day to supplement his calorie
intake, which have helped him maintain his weight since 6/10/23.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10149 Programs and services
Section (2) A facility shall provide or make available the following minimum
Description programs and services to residents:
(e) Medical Services
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
5

Allegation Youth was shot in the leg before detention and has not been
getting appropriate medical care. It was recommended he see a
surgeon as soon as possible but he did not for unknown reasons.
It was 3-4 weeks before a doctor saw youth at the facility. The
bullet was lodged in youth’s leg and eventually pushed itself out.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 6/28/23.
Complainant was a MDHHS Worker on an investigation on the
facility unrelated to these allegations. Complainant was told the
allegations by Youth A’s mother during a phone call. Complainant
noted Youth A did not mention either of these concerns during his
interview with her for the unrelated investigation.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/28/23.
Youth A reported when he arrived at the facility, he received
medical care for the bullet wound in his leg. Youth A stated the
medical team reported the surgeon wanted the bullet to exit his
leg by itself rather than doing surgery. Youth A reported he
received a shot in his calf area to numb the wound and
continuously gave him medication to ward off infection. Youth A
stated the facility medical staff cleaned and bandaged the wound
daily. Youth A reported eventually, the bullet began popping out of
his skin, so he asked if the medical staff could remove it, and they
did. Youth A reported the medical staff at the facility handled
everything appropriately and took care of it well, so he did not
have any concerns.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/28/23.
Nurse reported Youth A was first seen by a doctor in the
emergency room at Trinity Health for his bullet wound. Youth A
was then seen by the doctor at the facility. Youth A was seen by
the Physician Assistant at the facility regarding his bullet wound
on 4/7/23. Nurse reported Youth A was receiving wound checks
every day, which included cleaning & re-bandaging the wound.
Nurse reported he was prescribed and given antibiotics to combat
infection. Nurse reported the emergency room doctor and the
facility doctor both stated to leave the wound alone and the bullet
would exit on its own. Nurse reported bodies like to naturally take
care of things, and they were providing Youth A education
throughout on why this was the best course of action for him.
Nurse reported the facility also received a letter from the
Orthopedic Surgeon stating the bullet was through and through
and Youth A just needed to follow up with his primary care
physician. Nurse reported the doctor at the facility saw Youth A
every two weeks. Nurse reported the doctor saw Youth A on
6

6/9/23 and they could see the bullet near the top of the skin, so
the doctor made a little incision and the bullet fell out.
Probation Officer was interviewed via phone on 7/12/23.
Probation Officer reported she had no concerns for the care Youth
A received for his bullet wound. Probation Officer reported Youth
A saw a doctor at the facility regularly and consistently saw the
Nurse for check-ups.
Youth A’s Mother (Mother) was interviewed via phone on
7/12/23. Mother reported Youth A was prescribed antibiotics at the
hospital, which the facility gave him regularly. Mother reported
Youth A was prescribed pain medications as well, but Youth A
declined the pain medications, so the facility provided him with
Tylenol as needed. Mother reported Youth A saw the doctor
weeks after arriving and the doctor reported everything looked
good. Mother stated a few weeks after that, the bullet was ripping
Youth A’s skin open to push itself out, the doctor made an incision
at the top, and the bullet fell right out. Mother reported it was
noted in the discharge paperwork Youth A needed to see a
surgeon, but Youth A never saw a surgeon. Mother reported she
learned the surgeon wrote a letter stating he did not need to see
Youth A. Mother stated she has spoken to six other doctors, who
all stated Youth A should have been seen by a surgeon. Mother
confirmed the surgeon is not an employee of the facility.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Medical and Health Care Policy (rev. 12/22/22) states all
youth medical care shall be coordinated through the Health
Authority and VitalCore. Youth in need of medical care and
services beyond the scope of the medical staff and facilities
will be transported to local hospitals and clinics. Youth shall
have access to non-emergency in-house medical treatment
by request and access to emergency medical care on a 24-
hour basis.
• Trinity Health After Visit Summary dated 4/6/23 outlines
Youth A’s discharge requirements for the bullet wound in
his leg, including after care and prescribed medications.
Notes to schedule an appointment with Surgeon as soon as
possible.
• Letter from Surgeon dated 4/10/23 states Youth A “was
seen in the Emergency Room on 4/6/23 for GSW. The
bullet was through and through, there were no sutures or
7

staples. Patient may follow up with his Primary Care
Physician”.
• Medical Visits Youth A received at the facility from 4/7/23-
6/16/23.
o Medical notes show Youth A was seen daily for
wound cleaning and assessment by various nurses
at the facility.
o Youth A was first seen by Physician Assistant 1 on
4/7/23 as a follow up from hospital discharge.
o Youth A was seen by Physician Assistant 2 (PA 2)
on 4/11/23. PA 2 noted Youth A was advised to
follow up with Surgeon as soon as possible. PA 2
notes facility obtained communication with Surgeon
on 4/10/23 and Surgeon stated he does not feel
Youth A needed to be seen by general surgery and
can follow up with his primary care physician. PA 2
noted wounds were healing appropriately.
o Doctor met with Youth A on 4/14/23. Doctor notes
Youth A told him “His surgeon told him he can
simply leave the bullet in place but apparently the
mother is not comfortable with this”. Doctor noted
Youth A was in no distress, wounds were healing
well, and Youth A was moving normally. Doctor
noted “There is no urgency to removing this bullet. It
is possible that it would be best to leave it in place.
However, I feel we should allow another 4 weeks of
healing before considering removal. If he continues
to have pain after 4 weeks, it would be appropriate
to reassess a decision to leave the foreign body in
place”.
o Doctor met with Youth A on 6/2/23 for follow-up to
reassess the bullet in Youth A’s leg. Doctor notes
“This is progressing as expected and I would
anticipate within the next few weeks, the bullet will
likely be extruded”.
o Doctor met with Youth A on 6/9/23 for follow-up to
reassess the bullet in Youth A’s leg. Doctor noted
the bullet was able to be visualized and Youth A
requested the bullet be removed. Doctor made a
slight incision to Youth A’s leg and the bullet was
removed.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. Youth A was regularly seen and
assessed by medical professionals throughout the course of
treatment. Youth A’s plan of care was well documented and
8

followed according to medical notes. Youth A also expressed he
had no concerns with the care he received, and felt his wounds
were cared for appropriately.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
